questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent dislocation of the right shoulder. On examination, the orthopedician puts the patient in the supine position, abducts his arm to 90 degrees and externally rotates the shoulder with the bed as the fulcrum (as shown in the figure). But the boy does not allow the test to be performed. Which of the following clinical tests is being done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test described is the apprehension test, used for assessing anterior shoulder instability.

Apprehension test:

This is a test to detect an unstable shoulder. The shoulder is abducted and externally rotated. As the examiner loads the shoulder along the long axis of the arm, the patient becomes apprehensive and tries to resist any further movement by using his hand or by making the shoulder stiff through muscle spasms.

Explanation of other options:

Sulcus test (Option B): The Sulcus test is done for multidirectional and inferior glenohumeral instability.

O'Brien's test (Option C): This test is used to detect acromioclavicular joint pathology and tear of the superior labrum of the shoulder.

McMurray's test (Option D): Tests for medial and lateral meniscal tears of the knee joint. It is performed at varying angles of knee flexion. A click produced by the McMurray test is usually caused by a posterior peripheral tear of the meniscus and occurs between complete flexion of the knee and 90 degrees. 

Common orthopaedic tests:

questions.text: Identify the test being performed in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test elicited in the above image is the empty can test.

  • The empty can test is a clinical test used to test the integrity of the supraspinatus tendon. In this test, the shoulder is placed at 90° elevation in the scapular plane and full internal rotation (empty can). The patient is then asked to resist downward pressure exerted by the examiner at the patient's elbow or wrist.
  • The test is considered positive if there is weakness, pain or both. A positive test could indicate a supraspinatus tendon or muscle injury/tears, or other pathological conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Impingement test (Option A): Neer's impingement test is used to detect subacromial impingement syndrome (impingement of the supraspinatus tendon below the acromion). If the test is negative, passive horizontal adduction, internal rotation and elevation will be painless and positive if the pain is reproduced.

Hawkins Kennedy test (Option D): The Hawkins Kennedy test also tests for subacromial impingement syndrome (impingement of the supraspinatus tendon below the acromion). The patient's arm is placed in a 90-degree elevation in the scapular plane, with the elbow also flexed to 90 degrees. The examiner then stabilises the upper arm with one hand while using the other hand to internally rotate the arm fully. Pain around the anterolateral aspect of the shoulder is noted as a positive test.

Lift-off test (Option C): The lift-off test is a test for assessing the integrity of the subscapularis. The patient is asked to stand and place one arm behind his or her back with the dorsum of the hand resting against the mid-lumbar spine. The examiner then lifts the patient's hand off the back, and the patient is told to hold it there. The inability to do this signifies subscapularis weakness, possibly due to rupture.

questions.text: A 57-year-old automotive factory worker presents with complaints of weakness and pain in his right shoulder, specifically stating difficulty in lifting his right arm above his head for 2 weeks. He reports using his left arm to lift his right arm slightly, following which his right arm can be lifted without help. Which of the following muscles is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-described symptoms of difficulty in initiating abduction and the ability to lift the arm once the arm is raised slightly are suggestive of supraspinatus muscle injury.

  • The supraspinatus muscle is the most frequently injured among the rotator cuff muscles.
  • Patients often report pain anteriorly and superiorly to the glenohumeral joint during abduction.
  • The primary motion of the supraspinatus is the first 15 degrees of abduction of the arm, at which point the deltoid muscle continues the motion of abduction.
  • Therefore, as long as a patient can assist the injured rotator cuff at the beginning of abduction, he or she will be able to continue the motion unassisted thereafter.
  • This muscle and its tendon can be torn traumatically, but it is most often injured more insidiously because of repetitive movement, as is the likely cause in this case.

Explanation of other options:

Deltoid (Option A): The deltoid muscle takes over for the supraspinatus muscle in the abduction of the arm after about 15 degrees of abduction. The deltoid muscle is not injured in this case, as demonstrated by the patient's ability to initiate the lift motion by lifting the arm on the injured side with his other arm and then continuing the motion unassisted.

Infraspinatus (Option B): The action of the infraspinatus muscle is to laterally rotate the arm and is not involved in the abduction of the shoulder.

Subscapularis (Option C): The subscapularis is responsible for medial rotation and adduction of the arm.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency room with a history of falling on her right shoulder. She complains of shoulder pain and inability to raise her right arm. A physical exam reveals loss of sensation over the lateral side of the right arm. Radiology reveals a fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus. Which of the following muscles is supplied by the nerve that is most likely damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The nerve that supplies the lateral aspect of the arm is the lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm, which is a branch of the axillary nerve. Here, the Axillary nerve is damaged as it winds around the neck of the humerus. The 2 muscles supplied by the Axillary nerve are the deltoid and teres minor.

  • Three nerves are directly related to the humerus and are therefore liable to injury.
    • The axillary nerve at the surgical neck,
    • The radial nerve at the radial groove
    • The ulnar nerve is behind the medial epicondyle.
  • Fracture of the surgical neck of the humerus occurs commonly and damages the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles and gives rise to the lateral brachial cutaneous nerve, which carries the sensation from the lateral side of the arm. The loss of sensations in the lateral aspect of the arm is called the Regimental badge sign.
  • The axillary nerve arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It has a root value of C5-C6. It passes posteriorly through the quadrangular space, accompanied by the posterior circumflex humeral artery, and winds around the surgical neck of the humerus. Deltoid - arises from the lateral third of the clavicle and scapula, and is inserted on the deltoid tuberosity.
  • The Deltoid is the main abductor of the arm. The patient could not raise the arm because of paralysis of the deltoid muscle.
  • The teres minor muscle stabilises the shoulder joint and forms a rotator cuff along with the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, and subscapularis muscles. It rotates the arm laterally.

Explanation of other options:

Teres major (Option A): Teres major is involved with internal rotation and abduction of the shoulder, and the nerve supply is by the lower subscapular nerve.

Supraspinatus (Option C): The primary action of supraspinatus is initial abduction (0-15 degrees). It is supplied by the suprascapular nerve.

Infraspinatus (Option D): Infraspinatus is a powerful lateral rotator of the humerus and is supplied by the suprascapular nerve.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after falling from a bike, complaining of pain and swelling right arm. The X-ray taken revealed a fracture shaft of the humerus. Which of the following casts/splints can be used for the management of this fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Humerus fractures are usually treated conservatively with a cast application, mostly a hanging cast.

In a hanging cast, the weight of the limb and the cast are supposed to provide the necessary traction to keep the fracture aligned.

Fracture of the humerus shaft:

  • These fractures are very amenable to conservative treatment.
  • Most of the fractures are treated conservatively, either with a:
    • Hanging cast
    • Sarmiento brace
    • U-slab (coaptation splint).
  • In cases where a reduction is not possible by closed manipulation or if the fracture is very unstable, open reduction and internal fixation are required. Fixation can be achieved with a compression plate and screws, an interlocking intramedullary nail or an external fixator.

Explanation of other options:

Knuckle bender splint (Option B): A knuckle bender splint is used for managing claw hand deformity resulting from ulnar nerve palsy.

Aeroplane Splint (Option C): These are commonly used with brachial plexus injury, especially axillary nerve injury.

Above-elbow cast (Option D): Above-elbow casts are used for the conservative management of elbow injuries and supracondylar fractures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents with shoulder pain that worsens with abduction of the shoulder. She explains the pain to be less severe at the beginning and end of the movement. Which of the following can cause the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-mentioned symptoms are suggestive of painful arc syndrome, and all the mentioned options can cause this condition.

Painful arc syndrome:

  • Painful Arc syndrome is the condition in which the patient has no pain while abducting the shoulder from 0 to 69 degrees, severe pain between 60 and 120 degrees and again no pain between 120 and 180 degrees.
  • Common causes:
    • Minor tears of the supraspinatus tendon
    • Supraspinatus tendinitis (Option A ruled out)
    • Calcification of the supraspinatus tendon
    • Subacromial bursitis (Option B ruled out)
    • Fracture of the greater tuberosity (Option C ruled out)
  • In all these conditions, the space between the upper end of the humerus and the acromion gets compromised, so that during mid-abduction, the tendon of the rotator cuff gets nipped between the greater tuberosity and the acromion.
  • An X-ray of the shoulder may show a calcific deposit or a fracture of the greater tuberosity or acromion.
  • Treatment:
    • Physiotherapy and anti-inflammatory drugs.
    • If they do not work, then subacromial infiltration of steroids can be tried.
    • As a last resort, arthroscopic subacromial decompression and acromioplasty can be done.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after an episode of seizure. He complains of severe pain and inability to move his right shoulder. On examination arm is adducted, internally rotated, and the elbow flexed. Attempts to externally rotate and abduct the arm are extremely painful. What would you suspect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An adducted and internally rotated arm following a seizure episode strongly suggests posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

Posterior dislocation of the shoulder:

  • Patients with posterior shoulder dislocations are often overlooked, as it is not associated with gross deformities or severe pain. Further posterior dislocation is also difficult to pick up on X-rays.
  • They usually present with a history of a fall after an electric shock, epileptic seizure or severe trauma.
  • O/E, the shoulder would be locked in internal rotation and adduction and lack external rotation.
  • Orthogonal radiographs (anterior-posterior and axillary lateral) are necessary for proper diagnosis.
  • X-ray findings:
    • Empty glenoid sign
    • Light bulb sign
  • Posterior dislocation patients often have reverse Bankart and reverse Hill-Sachs lesions.
  • Treatment: Closed reduction and immobilisation

Explanation of other options:

Anterior dislocation (Option A): Results from a fall on outstretched hands. In anterior dislocation, the shoulder will be locked in abduction and external rotation. On examination, there will be flattening of the shoulder.

Fracture neck of humerus (Option C): Neck of femur fracture usually occurs following a fall on outstretched hands and presents with restricted shoulder movement, but no specific fixed position for the arm can be seen.

Inferior dislocation (Option D): Also known as luxation erecta, it occurs due to hyperabduction injury.

questions.text: Match the following lesions seen in anterior dislocation with their characteristics:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In anterior dislocation of the shoulder following pathological changes are seen.

  • Bankart's lesion: Ant. Dislocation causes stripping of the glenoid labrum along with the periosteum from the anterior surface of the glenoid and scapular neck. The head thus comes to lie in front of the scapular neck, in the pouch thereby created. In severe injuries, it may be avulsion of a piece of bone from the antero-inferior glenoid rim, called the Bony Bankart lesion.
  • Hill Sach's lesion: This is a depression on the humeral head in its postero-lateral quadrant, caused by impingement by the inferior edge of the glenoid on the head as it relocates.
  • Rounding of the anterior glenoid rim occurs as the head dislocates over it.
  • There may be associated fractures of the greater tuberosity of the humerus or the rim of the glenoid.

questions.text: 'Lift off' and 'Belly Press' tests are done to examine which of the following rotator cuff muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The subscapularis muscle is responsible for shoulder internal rotation, which can be tested with the belly press and lift-off test.

Lift-off test:

  • The lift-off test (Gerber lift-off test) is used to check for isolated rupture of the subscapularis tendon of the rotator cuff of the shoulder.
  • With the arm in internal rotation, the patient is asked to place the dorsum of the hand away from the back. If the patient can do this, the examiner applies an increasing counter-pressure against the patient's hand to test the strength of the subscapularis muscle.
  • If there is a tendon rupture or muscle insufficiency, the patient will be unable to actively lift the hand on the back against the examiner's resistance.

Belly press test:

  • In the belly press test, the patient is asked to place their hand on their abdomen and bring the elbow forward. The patient is then asked to press their hand into their abdomen.
  • If the subscapularis is torn, the patient will be unable to do this, and the elbow will move backwards.

Explanation of other options:

Teres minor (Option A): Hornblower's sign is used to assess the function of the teres minor muscle and is positive when the patient is unable to rotate the shoulder with the arm externally abducted and the elbow flexed to 90 degrees.

Supraspinatus (Option B): Supraspinatus strength can be tested in isolation with the empty can test. The patient is asked to raise their arms to 90 degrees abduction, 30 degrees forward flexion, and internal rotation (thumbs pointing to the floor, as if emptying an imaginary can). The examiner stands behind the patient and applies downward pressure on both arms, while the patient resists. The result is positive when the affected side is weaker than the unaffected side, suggesting a tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

Infraspinatus (Option D): Infraspinatus can be tested with resisted external rotation. The patient stands holding his or her arms close to the body and the elbows flexed to 90 degrees. He or she is instructed to externally rotate both arms while the examiner applies resistance; lack of power on one side signifies weakness of the infraspinatus.

Rotator cuff muscle tests:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male sustained a shoulder injury while falling when he was hanging from a bar. He complains of severe shoulder pain and restricted movement, and shoulder dislocation was suspected. The weakest portion of the shoulder joint capsule is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The inferior portion of the shoulder joint capsule is the weakest, being least reinforced by ligaments and muscles.

  • The shoulder joint is weakest inferiorly, but dislocates anteriorly because it is the direction of force that decides the dislocation, but never the anatomical weakness of a particular joint.
  • For eg, the force that causes anterior dislocation (Abduction and external rotation) is much more common in throwing objects like a ball or a javelin as compared to the force that causes inferior dislocation.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior (Option A): The anterior portion of the shoulder joint capsule is supported well by the subscapularis muscle fibres of attachment of the deltoid. It is the common site for shoulder dislocation, although it's not the weakest part of the joint capsule.

Posterior (Option B): Posteriorly, the joint capsule of the shoulder joint is strengthened by the fibres of attachment of the trapezius.

Superior (Option D): The shoulder joint capsule superiorly is strengthened by the acromioclavicular ligament and the fibres of the attachment of trapezius.

Most common types, subtypes, and complications related to shoulder injury:

choices.text: It can result from tendinitis caused by inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons
The supraspinatus tendon is most often involved
Shoulder pain worsens with overhead abduction.
Surgical decompression of the subacromial space is frequently indicated

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about impingement syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Surgical decompression of the subacromial space is the last resort in individuals with impingement syndrome when all other conservative treatment modalities fail.

Impingement syndrome:

  • Impingement syndrome occurs in middle-aged individuals, especially those involved in baseball, tennis, swimming, or occupations that require repeated elevation of the arm.
  • The syndrome likely represents a combination of extrinsic compression and intrinsic degeneration.
    • Extrinsic compression is from the anterior acromion, the coracoacromial ligament, and the AC joint.
    • Intrinsic degeneration occurs in the supraspinatus, and the resultant weakness causes narrowing of the subacromial space and abutment of the rotator cuff against the acromion.
  • Tendinitis of the rotator cuff is the major cause of a painful shoulder and is caused by inflammation of the tendons. (Option A ruled out)
  • Supraspinatus is most commonly involved due to: (Option B ruled out)
    • Repeated impingement between the humeral head, acromion and coracoacromial ligament
    • Reduction in its blood supply that occurs with abduction of the arm. 

Clinical features:

  • Patients complain of a dull aching in the shoulder, which may interfere with sleep.
  • Severe pain is experienced when the arm is actively abducted into an overhead position. (Option C ruled out)
  • Tenderness is present over the lateral aspect of the humeral head just below the acromion.

Stages of progression of impingement syndrome:

  • Subacute tendinitis - the "painful arc syndrome", due to vascular congestion, microscopic haemorrhage and oedema
  • Chronic tendinitis - recurrent shoulder pain due to tendinitis and fibrosis
  • Cuff disruption - recurrent pain, weakness and loss of movement due to tears in the rotator cuff.

Treatment:

  • NSAIDs, local glucocorticoid injection, and physical therapy may relieve symptoms.
  • Surgical decompression of the subacromial space may be rarely indicated in patients refractory to conservative treatment.

choices.text: It is the most common type of shoulder dislocation
The patient keeps his arm in a saluting position
Injury to the brachial plexus may occur

questions.text: A 20-year-old boy presents to the ER after falling on outstretched hands while playing football. He complains of severe right shoulder pain and inability to move the joint. On examination, there is a loss of contour of the shoulder with the arm being in abduction and external rotation. Which of the following is true about his likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common type of anterior dislocation of the shoulder is subcoracoid, and the saluting position is seen in inferior dislocation of the shoulder. Injury to the brachial plexus is very rare.

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder is the most common type of shoulder dislocation. The head of the humerus comes out of the glenoid cavity and lies anteriorly. (Option A ruled out)

Types of anterior shoulder dislocation:

  • Subglenoid -The Humeral head lies in front of the glenoid.
  • Subcoracoid -The head lies below the coracoid process. This is the most common type of anterior shoulder dislocation.
  • Subclavicular (infraclavicular)-The head lies below the clavicle.
  • Intrathoracic- It is very rare.

Mechanism of Injury: Two types of injury may lead to anterior dislocation:

  • Indirect force (most common): Abduction, external rotation and extension force due to a fall on outstretched hands or during throwing.
  • Direct force (less common): Direct blow on the shoulder from posterior or posterior lateral, such as a fall on the elbow directed backwards and outward.

Clinical features of anterior dislocation:

  • Severe pain and inability to move the shoulder.
  • The patient keeps his arm by the side of his body in a position of abduction and external rotation.
  • Adduction and internal rotations are restricted.
  • Loss of the normal round contour of the shoulder.
  • The humeral head is palpable anteriorly in the subcoracoid region, beneath the clavicle.
  • Anterior fullness in the shoulder.

Clinical tests for anterior shoulder dislocation:

  • Dugas test: The patient can't bring the elbow close to the body & put the hand on his opposite shoulder.
  • Callaway's test: In dislocation vertical circumference of the axilla is increased compared to the normal side.
  • Hamilton ruler test: Because of flattening of the shoulder, it is possible to place a ruler on the lateral side of the arm, and it touches the acromion & lateral condyle of the humerus simultaneously (in normal, it would not due to the shoulder contour)
  • Bryant's test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level

Complications of Anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

  • Recurrent dislocation is the most common complication
  • Brachial plexus injury, especially the posterior cord (Option D ruled out)
  • Axillary artery may be damaged, especially if the vessel is atheromatous, or during attempted late reduction.
  • The most common early complication of anterior dislocation of the shoulder is axillary nerve injury. There is consequent paralysis of the deltoid muscle, with a small area of anaesthesia at the lateral aspect of the upper arm. Regimental badge sign: Area of anaesthesia around the deltoid due to injury to the axillary nerve.

Treatment of anterior dislocation:

  • Anterior dislocation of the shoulder is an emergency and has to be immediately reduced. Reduction should be gentle and should be done preferably under general anaesthesia.
  • After the reduction, the arm should be immobilised for 3 weeks by chest arm strapping.

Methods of reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation: 

  • Kocher's manoeuvre: The most commonly used method is Kocher's method.
    The various steps of this method of reduction are (remember TEAM) T- Traction (along the line of the humerus), E- External (lateral) rotation of arms, A- Adduction of arm, M- Medial (internal) rotation of the arm.
  • Stimson's gravity method: The patient is left prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. Thus, the weight of the limb helps in reduction.
  • Hippocrates' manoeuvre: Reduction is done by axial traction in the semi-abducted arm, with countertraction given by placing the foot in the axilla.

questions.text: A Tennis player presents with a history of multiple episodes of spontaneous shoulder dislocation due to a glenoid labrum injury. Now he states that he can correct his dislocations. This condition most likely is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A history of multiple episodes of shoulder dislocation due to glenoid labrum injury in an individual who can self-reduce the dislocation is likely to have recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation.

  • Shoulder dislocation is the most common joint dislocation in the body, with anterior shoulder dislocation being the most common.
  • Recurrent shoulder dislocation is the most common complication of shoulder dislocation. The younger the patient greater the risk.
  • Clinical features: Dislocation with trivial trauma, daily activities and sleep.
  • Danger position: Abduction, external rotation.

Cause of recurrence:

Following the first dislocation, irreversible damage can occur to stabilising structures. If there is poor healing of stabilisers, shoulder stability is lost, and recurrent dislocation occurs even in trivial trauma.

Common lesions associated with recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation:

  • Bankart lesion
  • Bony Bankart lesion
  • Hill Sach's lesion

Surgeries for recurrent shoulder dislocation:

Explanation of other options:

Recurrent posterior shoulder dislocation (Option B): Posterior shoulder dislocation is associated with epileptiform convulsion or as a consequence of an electric shock.

Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion (Option C): It is due to posterior shoulder dislocation. Microavulsion is seen on the anteromedial aspect of the humeral head.

Inferior shoulder dislocation (Option D): Also known as Luxatio Erecta, it is a rare type of shoulder dislocation where the head of the humerus comes to lie in the subglenoid position.

questions.text: A 25-year-old weightlifter complains of recurrent pain and a sensation of shoulder instability during pushing movements. During examination, an axial force applied during horizontal adduction of the arm causes a sudden jerk or clunk. Which of the following tests is being performed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test being performed on the individual is the Jerk Test, which is specifically used to assess posterior instability of the glenohumeral joint.

Jerk test/Jahnke test:

  • This can be performed with the patient standing or sitting. The examiner holds the patient's elbow with one hand and stabilises the scapula with the other hand.
  • The shoulder is then flexed to 90°, internally rotated and adducted, and an axial load is applied to the elbow. The shoulder may subluxate or dislocate posteriorly with a sudden jerk.
  • Now arm is gradually abducted, the humeral head may reduce back onto the glenoid.

Explanation of other options:

Fulcrum test (Option A): The fulcrum test is used to evaluate anterior glenohumeral instability. With the patient lying supine, the arm is abducted to 90 degrees, and the examiner places one hand behind the patient's shoulder to act as a fulcrum over which the humeral head is levered forward by extending and laterally rotating the arm.

Sulcus test (Option C): The Sulcus test is done for multidirectional and inferior glenohumeral instability.

Crank test (Option D): The Crank test is used to detect glenoid labrum tears.

Tests for shoulder instability:

questions.text: Which of the following shoulder positions presents the greatest risk for anterior dislocations of the shoulder, especially in a patient suffering from recurrent dislocations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Abduction and external rotation is the position in which most of the recurrent shoulder dislocations occur. E.g. throwing a ball, playing a smash in badminton or volleyball, sleeping with a hand under the head, etc.

Rarely does a direct blow on the front of the shoulder cause the head of the humerus to be pushed out posteriorly.

questions.text: A 24-year-old football player, while playing, sustained an injury to his left shoulder. He complains of severe pain and inability to move his shoulder. On examination, there is flattening of the shoulder and sensory loss over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The football player is suspected to have an anterior dislocation of the shoulder, which caused axillary nerve injury, resulting in the loss of sensation in the lateral aspect of the shoulder.

  • Injury to the axillary nerve may result in paralysis of the deltoid muscle, with a small area of anaesthesia over the lateral aspect of the shoulder, which is termed the Regimental badge area.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed by asking the patient to try to abduct the shoulder. Though shoulder abduction may not be possible because of pain, one can feel the absence of contraction of the deltoid.
  • Treatment is conservative, and the prognosis is good.

Explanation of other options:

Radial nerve (Option B): Radial nerve is commonly injured in the fracture of shaft of humerus and presents with wrist drop and paresthesia dorsum of the 1st web space.

Ulnar nerve (Option C): Fracture of the medial condyle of the humerus is usually associated with ulnar nerve injury. Damage to the nerve can result in claw-hand deformity.

Median nerve (Option D): Median nerve injuries are common with supracondylar fractures of the humerus. Patients can present with ape thumb deformity.

Shoulder Pathologies and the Nerve Involved:

questions.text: In the Putti-Platt operation, the double breasting of which muscle is done to limit external rotation of the shoulder, thereby preventing recurrences:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Putti-Platt operation involves the double-breasting of the subscapularis tendon and is a surgical procedure performed for recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Surgeries for recurrent shoulder dislocation:

Putti-Platt operation:

  • Double-breasting of the subscapularis tendon is performed to limit external rotation, thereby preventing recurrences.

Bankart's operation:

  • The glenoid labrum and capsule are re-attached to the front of the glenoid rim. This is a technically demanding procedure, but has become simpler with the use of special fixation devices called anchors.

Bristow's operation:

  • In this operation, the coracoid process, along with its attached muscles, is osteotomized at its base and fixed to the lower half of the anterior margin of the glenoid. The muscles attached to the coracoid provide a dynamic anterior support to the head of the humerus.

Arthroscopic Bankart repair:

  • With the development of arthroscopic techniques, it has become possible to stabilise a recurrently unstable shoulder arthroscopically. Apart from being a more cosmetic option, rehabilitation after arthroscopic repair is faster and better. It is a technically demanding operation, and the anchor sutures used for repair are expensive.

questions.text: A 40-year-old painter presents with shoulder pain that worsens when lifting his arm overhead. On examination, pain is noted during mid-range abduction but relieved at the extremes of movement. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above-explained symptoms of shoulder pain worsening on shoulder abduction and relieved at extremes of movement are typical of painful arc syndrome. A complete supraspinatus tear is unlikely to cause this condition.

Painful arc syndrome:

  • Painful arc syndrome is the condition in which a patient suffers shoulder pain between 60 - 120 degrees of abduction, and other ranges are pain-free.
  • Mechanism - The subacromial space is the minimum at this range as the greater tuberosity occupies the space under the acromion.
  • Painful arc syndrome is often due to impingement of the supraspinatus tendon or subacromial bursa between the humeral head and acromion during arm elevation.

Causes of Painful arc syndrome:

  • Subacromial Bursitis
  • Supraspinatus Tendinitis
  • Supraspinatus Tears
  • Calcific Tendinitis

Common tests for evaluating impingement:

  • Neer's impingement test
  • Hawkins' Kennedy test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old manual labourer presents with shoulder pain aggravated by lifting his arm overhead. During the examination, Neer's impingement test was performed, and the test elicited pain at extremes of movement. Which of the following conditions is most likely indicated by this test?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario described above is indicative of impingement syndrome, which is demonstrated by a positive Neer's impingement test.

Neer's impingement syndrome:

  • Neer's test is used for the diagnosis of impingement syndrome of the shoulder.
  • The patient is seated, and the examiner passively internally rotates and forward flexes the shoulder. If the patient experiences pain, then the test is positive.

Explanation of other options:

Periarthritis shoulder (Option B): This is a disease of unknown aetiology where the glenohumeral joint becomes painful and stiff because of the loss of resilience of the joint capsule, possibly with adhesions between its folds. Often, there is a history of preceding trauma. The disease is common in diabetics.

Rotator cuff tears (Option C): Rotator cuff tears are mostly associated with a tear of the supraspinatus muscle and are usually tested with the empty can test and arm drop test. The Neer test can also be positive, but it is less specific.

The long head of biceps tendinitis (Option D): The long head of biceps tendinitis usually occurs together with rotator cuff impingement; rarely, it presents as an isolated problem in young people after unaccustomed shoulder strain. Tenderness is sharply localised to the bicipital groove. Two manoeuvres that often cause pain are: resisted flexion with the elbow straight and the forearm supinated (Speed's test) and resisted supination of the forearm with the elbow bent (Yergason's test).

questions.text: A carpenter complains of weakness while performing internal rotation of his shoulder. On examination, when he is asked to press his abdomen with his palm, he is unable to maintain the elbow in a flexed position; instead, there is wrist flexion. Which muscle is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the above case, the test elicited is the belly press test, which is used to evaluate subscapularis muscle tears.

Belly press test:

  • The belly press test is used to identify tears of the subscapularis muscle.
  • In the belly press test:
    • The patient is asked to press his belly with his palm.
    • Here we are testing for internal rotation power (subscapularis)
    • In subscapularis tear - the patient will be unable to press his belly; however, he compensates by Wrist flexion, Shoulder adduction and Shoulder extension.

questions.text: A 55-year-old diabetic woman presents with severe pain and stiffness in the right shoulder for the last 3 months. O/E, there is a global restriction of both active and passive movements of the right shoulder. The X-ray is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Global restriction of both active and passive movements of the shoulder is seen in post-traumatic stiffness and adhesive capsulitis.

In this patient, the diagnosis is adhesive capsulitis because there is no history of trauma, the X-ray is normal, and she is diabetic.

Adhesive capsulitis:

  • Adhesive capsulitis is also called Periarthritis or Frozen shoulder.
  • It is an idiopathic condition characterised by a global reduction in the passive and active range of motion of the shoulder due to fibrosis and adhesions in the capsule.e
  • It is usually self-limiting, but it takes a lot of time for that.
  • It is usually treated conservatively with physiotherapy. Surgery is rarely indicated.

Explanation of other options:

Rotator cuff tear (Option A): Progressive fibrosis and disruption of the rotator cuff can result in either a partial or full-thickness tear of the muscles of the rotator cuff. The patient is usually aged over 45 and gives a history of refractory shoulder pain with increasing stiffness and weakness. The patient presents with severe pain and inability to abduct the arm.

Shoulder osteoarthritis (Option B): The patient is usually aged 50-60 years and may give a history of injury, shoulder dislocation or a previous painful arc syndrome. There is usually little to see, but shoulder movements are restricted in all directions. Pain is common, particularly at night. X-rays show distortion of the joint, bone sclerosis and osteophyte formation; the articular space may be narrowed or may show calcification.

Septic arthritis (Option D): Acute septic arthritis is associated with tenderness and swelling localised to the joint. Movement at the joint is painful and restricted. Diagnosis is confirmed with aspiration of synovial fluid under strict aseptic conditions, and the fluid is examined for inflammatory cells.
